document.title: Pell’s equation and side and diagonal numbers

A ^ n = matrix[[(1 - square-root@(2)) ^ n / 2 + (1 + square-root@(2)) ^ n / 2, (- (1 - square-root@(2)) ^ n / (2 * square-root@(2))) + (1 + square-root@(2)) ^ n / (2 * square-root@(2))], [(- (1 - square-root@(2)) ^ n / square-root@(2)) + (1 + square-root@(2)) ^ n / square-root@(2), (1 - square-root@(2)) ^ n / 2 + (1 + square-root@(2)) ^ n / 2]]

matrix[[a _ (n + 1)], [d _ (n + 1)]] = matrix[[((1 / 2) * (1 - square-root@(2)) ^ n - (1 - square-root@(2)) ^ n / (2 * square-root@(2))) + (1 / 2) * (1 + square-root@(2)) ^ n + (1 + square-root@(2)) ^ n / (2 * square-root@(2))], [((1 / 2) * (1 - square-root@(2)) ^ n - (1 - square-root@(2)) ^ n / square-root@(2)) + (1 / 2) * (1 + square-root@(2)) ^ n + (1 + square-root@(2)) ^ n / square-root@(2)]]

quote.p:
Given any number not a square, then there are an infinite number of squares which, when multiplied by the given number, make a square when unity is added.
Example. Given 3, a nonsquare number; this number multiplied by the square number 1, and 1 being added, produces 4, which is a square.
Moreover, the same 3 multiplied by the square 16, with 1 added makes 49, which is a square.
And instead of 1 and 16, an infinite number of squares may be found showing the same property; I demand, however, a general rule, any number being given which is not a square.
It is sought, for example, to find a square which when multiplied into 149, 109, 433, etc., becomes a square when unity is added.

para.p: Ozanam [, pp. 503–516], Liv. III, Quest. XXVI.

formulae@(p _ n = a _ n * p _ (n - 1) + p _ (n - 2), q _ n = a _ n * q _ (n - 1) + q _ (n - 2))

para.p:
Hardy and Wright [, p. 144, Theorem 176]. A continued fraction
[
a 0
,
a 1
, … ]
is said to be periodic if there is some
≥ L 0
and some
≥ k 1
such that
=
a
+ l k
a l
for all
≥ l L
.

If
= x
[
a 0
,
a 1
, … ]
is a periodic continued fraction, then
x
is a quadratic surd.

Math.text: overline@(list@(a _ L, ldots, a _ ((L + k) - 1))) = list@(a _ L, a _ (L + 1), ldots) = (a _ L) ^ prime

absent = list@(a _ 0, ldots, a _ (L - 1), (a _ L) ^ prime)
absent = list@(a _ 0, ldots, a _ (L - 1), overline@(list@(a _ L, ldots, a _ ((L + k) - 1))))
absent = list@(a _ 0, ldots, a _ (L - 1), overline@(list@(a _ L, ldots, a _ ((L + k) - 1))))

218

Math.text: square-root@(218) = 14 + continued-fraction@(1, 1 + continued-fraction@(1, 3 + continued-fraction@(1, 3 + continued-fraction@(1, 1 + continued-fraction@(1, (28 + square-root@(218)) - 14)))))
absent = 14 + continued-fraction@(1, 1 + continued-fraction@(1, 3 + continued-fraction@(1, 3 + continued-fraction@(1, 1 + continued-fraction@(1, (28 + square-root@(218)) - 14)))))
x - 14 = continued-fraction@(1, 1 + continued-fraction@(1, 3 + continued-fraction@(1, 3 + continued-fraction@(1, 1 + continued-fraction@(1, (28 + x) - 14)))))
t = continued-fraction@(1, 1 + continued-fraction@(1, 3 + continued-fraction@(1, 3 + continued-fraction@(1, 1 + continued-fraction@(1, 28 + t)))))
